text: so attention deficit hyperactivity
disorder is a very misunderstood
psychiatric disorder uh it's real it can
literally 5 to 8% of the population has
this this disorder and the important
part is that it's a variation on normal
so you have children who are more
hyperactive more impulsive more
inattentive than other children their
developmental age and it is a lifetime
Disorder so that it will look slightly
different obviously between a
preschooler a schoolage child a high
school student or an adult but there's
still a consistency of inattention
impulsivity and hyperactivity and in
fact most often we see that
hyperactivity disappears as someone gets
older and so when they're in their late
adolescence and early adulthood um that
symptom seems to go away and if we are
able to look at the brains of children
who have
ADHD uh they look different than uh
typical uh children and in fact an
important study was done about 15 years
ago that followed kids over a decade who
had attention deficit hyperactivity
disorder uh and these were children who
had never taken medication this was a
group of kids who met the diagnostic
criteria were studied at the National
Institute of Mental Health and had
Parents who said under no circumstances
will we treat our kids with uh rlin or
any kind of uh medication and we're
compared to a group of typical or normal
uh children the same age and they found
that there were significant differences
in the frontal lobe and in the
cerebellum the frontal lobe is where you
have your executive functioning where
you're able to prioritize which item
should I attack first what's the
important thing that I should do today
and how do I get that that done before I
go to item 2 3 4 and five that are uh
tackling me uh as far as my daily tasks
and the cerebellum is where coordination
is and so it's really interesting that
as these kids got older and HD
adolescence their cerebellum started to
look more like the same size as the
typical normal kids and it would explain
why the hyperactivity uh symptom seems
to diminish and yet the frontal loopes
still seemed significantly uh smaller
than uh the typical normal
child so I think it's important for us
to realize that our brains are filled
with
neurotransmitters um these are brain
chemicals that move from one part of the
brain to another and take messages with
them the three big neurotransmitters
would be dopamine norepinephrine and
serotonin and when you have attension
deficit hyperactivity disorder you use
your dopamine and your neuro epinephrine
faster in your brain than the average
person and when you don't have enough of
that uh you become inattentive or you
become more impulsive or you're more
hyperactive um The Centers of the brain
that are smaller on these patients who
have ADHD seem to be very rich in
dopamine and in neopine phrine so it's
very nice that there's a neuroanatomical
reason for us to sure that the chemicals
that we're talking about are equal now
you can't take dopamine or neopine or
even serotonin and get it to your brain
because there's something in our body
called the blood brain barrier protects
the brain and the spinal cord and the
neurotransmitters those brain chemicals
that move back and forth in that space
and so we give medications that kind of
um change um or trick the brain so that
we allow dopamine or norepinephrine in
the case of kids with ADHD to hang
around longer in the brain uh to make
them look more typical um these
medications whether they're rlin um
which is uh very similar to Focalin and
a group that's called meth
methylamphetamine versus dextra
amphetamine or dexadrin or adderal on
which is a little more potent um both of
them create about the same types of um
chemical response which is to make
dopamine and norepinephrine more
available but they're short acting
medicines they last anywhere from 4
hours to about 10 hours and once the
medicine's out of your system you're
right back to where you were at Baseline
so there is really nothing permanent
about this this is a treatment not a
cure
